G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as this is a civil action for damages arising out of a residential tenancy located within the territorial jurisdiction of the Lowell District Court and the amount in controversy is within the Court’s jurisdictional limits.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as this is a civil action for damages arising out of a residential tenancy located within the territorial jurisdiction of the Lowell District Court and the amount in controversy is within the Court’s jurisdictional limits.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Lowell District Court because the Premises are located in Lowell, Middlesex County, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this action occurred within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction. See G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The mold growth and related moisture condition constitute violations of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to the requirements that a dwelling be maintained in a sanitary and safe condition, free from chronic dampness and mold, with adequate ventilation in bathrooms. See 105 C.M.R. 410.020, 410.500, 410.750.

105 C.M.R. 410.020, 410.500, 410.750.proposition: The mold growth and related moisture condition constitute violations of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to the requirements that a dwelling be maintained in a sanitary and safe condition, free from chronic dampness and mold, with adequate ventilation in bathrooms. See 105 C.M.R. 410.020, 410.500, 410.750.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord is prohibited from “directly or indirectly interfering with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant,” and is liable for “actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee,” where such interference is caused by the landlord or persons acting on the landlord’s behalf.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest on all monetary awards, as allowed by law, including G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of a dwelling due to housing‑code violations, defective conditions, or failure to make necessary repairs can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.support_reasoning: The case does recognize that substantial interference with tenants’ quiet enjoyment—here, severe nighttime noise from a bar—can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment and justify nonpayment of rent. However, the interference in Blackett arises from commercial noise, not from housing-code violations, defective physical conditions, or a failure to make necessary repairs. The opinion therefore supports the broader notion that substantial interference can breach quiet enjoyment, but it does not specifically involve or discuss housing‑code violations or defective/ unrepaired conditions as the source of that interference.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959) (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services). Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375, 381 (1942) (intrusions of smoke and soot over a substantial period of time due to a defective boiler).

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–85 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of a dwelling due to housing‑code violations, defective conditions, or failure to make necessary repairs can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The case does recognize that substantial interference with tenants’ use and enjoyment of their homes can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but the interference at issue here is criminal drug activity and the landlord’s failure to take measures to remove nontenants—not housing‑code violations, defective physical conditions, or failure to make repairs. The court expressly cabins those types of issues under the warranty of habitability and declines to expand that warranty to cover nonphysical conditions. Thus, this opinion supports a quieter‑enjoyment theory based on third‑party criminal activity, not on code violations or defective/unrepaired conditions, and does not support the proposition as worded.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development… then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of a dwelling due to housing‑code violations, defective conditions, or failure to make necessary repairs can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the scope of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and explicitly notes that a landlord’s negligent failure to repair known defects in leased premises has repeatedly been held to violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment. It cites prior cases involving defective conditions and failures to make repairs (e.g., leaky roof, failure to keep an apartment habitable) as classic § 14 breaches, confirming that substantial interference with use and enjoyment due to such conditions can constitute a breach. Although the particular issue here is lead paint and attorney’s fees, the court reaffirms the broader principle stated in the proposition.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.relevant_excerpt: “Twelve years later, in Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, supra, we rejected a claim that a violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, could be imposed only if it were proved that a landlord was reckless in disregarding his tenant’s rights, and we concluded that negligent conduct, conduct involving ‘some degree of fault,’ by a landlord could support the imposition of liability under § 14. Id. at 789. We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of a dwelling due to housing‑code violations, defective conditions, or failure to make necessary repairs can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The court extensively discusses G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment, explaining that ‘quiet enjoyment’ means freedom from serious interferences with the tenancy and tying liability to failure to maintain sanitary, code‑compliant conditions. It repeatedly links Gem’s violation of its duty to maintain sanitary, watertight premises and compliance with the State Sanitary Code to interference with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment, and holds that such unsanitary, defective conditions can form the basis of a quiet‑enjoyment claim under § 14. This aligns with the proposition that substantial interference via housing‑code violations or defective conditions can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy…. The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. See 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.500; Crowell v. McCaffrey…; Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway…. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.proposition: The statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment supplements the common‑law covenant recognized in cases such as Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33 (1929), and guarantees tenants the right to freedom from serious and repeated interferences with their tenancy caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.support_reasoning: The opinion is a common‑law quiet enjoyment / nuisance / trespass case and does not discuss any statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. It recognizes an implied covenant and the tenant’s right to relief for substantial and continued interference caused by the landlord’s acts or authorized acts, but it nowhere addresses how a statutory covenant ‘supplements’ that common‑law covenant. Thus the case supports the common‑law aspect of the proposition but not the specifically statutory component stated in the claimed proposition.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.relevant_excerpt: “The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… If a landlord authorizes acts to be done which cause substantial injury to the tenant in the peaceful enjoyment of the demised premises and such a result is the natural and probable consequence of the acts so authorized, the landlord is liable therefor.… It is evident from the facts found that there has been a substantial and continued interference with the plaintiff’s beneficial enjoyment of the leased premises….”

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: The mold condition also renders the Premises unfit for human habitation and in violation of the implied warranty of habitability, as recognized by the Supreme Judicial Court in Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), and its progeny.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: The excerpt is a separate opinion (concurring/dissenting) discussing the implied warranty of habitability in general and the interaction with the State Sanitary Code; it does not address mold specifically or hold that any particular condition (such as mold) renders premises unfit. While Hemingway is indeed the seminal Massachusetts case recognizing an implied warranty of habitability for residential premises, this passage does not itself establish that a mold condition is uninhabitable, so using it as direct authority for that specific proposition overstates what the case holds. The case supports the existence of an implied warranty tied to code and habitability standards, but not the specific application to mold in this excerpt.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “I agree with the majority of the court that, at least as to dwelling units, the time has come to reconsider the rule so long imbedded in our law of landlord and tenant that ‘[t]here is no implied agreement, apart from fraud, that the demised premises are or will continue to be fit for occupancy or safe and in good repair ….’ … The opinion of the court … [reverses] the present common law rule that ‘[t]here is no implied agreement, apart from fraud, that the demised premises are or will continue to be fit for occupancy or safe and in good repair….’”}

Hemingway v. Bresky, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 1.raw_text: Hemingway v. Bresky, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 184, 186–87 (1983)
Hemingway v. Bresky, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 1.proposition: Violations of the State Sanitary Code are evidence of breaches of both the implied warranty of habitability and the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–201 (1973) (sanitary code violations render premises uninhabitable); Hemingway v. Bresky, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 184, 186–87 (1983) (sanitary code violations support quiet enjoyment damages); Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400–01 (1982) (failure to correct code violations can constitute quiet enjoyment breach).
Hemingway v. Bresky, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 1.support_reasoning:
The quoted opinion is a criminal case about search warrants, probable cause, scope of warrants, and sufficiency of evidence for receiving stolen property. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, the State Sanitary Code, implied warranty of habitability, or covenant of quiet enjoyment. Accordingly, it cannot support the proposition that sanitary code violations are evidence of breaches of habitability or quiet enjoyment.

The correct housing-related Hemingway case is Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), not this criminal case involving Joylene LaBelle (Hemingway v. Bresky).
Hemingway v. Bresky, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 1.relevant_excerpt: The defendant was found guilty by a six-member jury in a District Court on a complaint framed under G. L. c. 266, § 60. She was sentenced to a term of one year in a house of correction, three months to be served and the balance suspended. The trial judge granted her motion for a stay of execution of sentence pending appeal. On appeal she claims that a motion to suppress evidence was erroneously denied because there was no probable cause to issue the search warrant under which the evidence in question was found, that the warrant itself was invalid because it contained a general clause, and that even if the warrant were partially valid, the search exceeded the scope of the valid clauses.

Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400\u.proposition: Violations of the State Sanitary Code are evidence of breaches of both the implied warranty of habitability and the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–201 (1973) (sanitary code violations render premises uninhabitable); Hemingway v. Bresky, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 184, 186–87 (1983) (sanitary code violations support quiet enjoyment damages); Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400–01 (1982) (failure to correct code violations can constitute quiet enjoyment breach).
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400\u.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss the implied warranty of habitability or articulate any rule that State Sanitary Code violations are evidence of a breach of that warranty; the only references to habitability are in the procedural history. As to quiet enjoyment, the court addresses only the measure and duplication of damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and G.L. c. 93A; it does not state that failure to correct sanitary code violations constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment or analyze code violations as evidence of such a breach. Thus Wolfberg is not authority for the specific proposition claimed, even though the landlord was found (by the trial judge) to have violated quiet enjoyment on these facts.
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400\u.relevant_excerpt: “The judge awarded $990 (three months’ rent) to the tenants on a finding that the landlord had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14, the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. General Laws c. 186, § 14, as amended by St. 1974, c. 192, § 1, allows tenants to recover ‘actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater,’ for violation of that statute. … We now hold that, where a tenant has been awarded in excess of both three months’ rent and actual damages under G. L. c. 93A on claims based upon the same set of facts as in a concurrent claim for damages for violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, the recovery of damages under G. L. c. 186, § 14, would be duplicative and, therefore, will not be allowed.”

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761–62 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Defendant is liable to Plaintiff for her actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, together with costs of the action and reasonable attorney’s fees. See, e.g., Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761–62 (1979) (discussing multiple‑damage remedy and mandatory attorney’s fee provision of § 14).
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The court directly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14, stating that a lessor who violates the statute is liable for either actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and also for costs including a reasonable attorney’s fee. The opinion describes the three‑months’ rent component as a minimum, multiple‑damage remedy where actual damages are slight or hard to prove, and later emphasizes that attorney’s fees are explicitly and mandatorily authorized by § 14. This aligns with the proposition’s description of the damages structure and mandatory fee provision.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that a lessor who commits any act in violation of that section (including interference ‘with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises’) shall ‘be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.’ … Section 14 allows a minimum recovery of three months’ rent as an incentive to the pursuit of relief where the actual and consequential damages are slight or are difficult to prove.”
